profileText: A Representative from South Carolina; born in Winnsboro, Fairfield County, S.C., March 7, 1831; attended the Academy of Mount Zion Institute in Winnsboro; was graduated from South Carolina College at Columbia in 1850 and from South Carolina Medical College at Charleston in 1853; engaged in the practice of medicine in Winnsboro from 1853 to 1861; also engaged as a planter; volunteered in the Confederate Army as a private and served throughout the Civil War, attaining the rank of brigadier general; member of the State constitutional convention in 1865; served in the State senate in 1866; chairman of the South Carolina delegation in the Democratic National Convention in 1876; delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1880; elected comptroller general of South Carolina by the legislature, to fill a vacancy, in 1881; elected to the Forty-eighth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of John H. Evins and served from December 8, 1884, to March 3, 1885; was not a candidate for renomination in 1884; retired from active politics and again engaged in planting at ``Farmington,'' near Winnsboro; died in Winnsboro, S.C., January 12, 1898; interment in the Episcopal Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Austin, J. Luke. General John Bratton: Sumter to Appomattox, in Letters to His Wife. Sewanee, Tenn: Proctor's Hall Press, 2003.
Bratton, John. Letters of John Bratton to His Wife. [N.p., 1942].

researchRecord.name: 1861-1865, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: Bound typescripts of Civil War letters from John Bratton with the 6th South Carolina Regiment to his wife, Betty DuBose Bratton in and near Winnsboro, S.C. The letters describe army life at different camps in South Carolina, Tennessee, and Virginia; battles in which John Bratton took part; and the behavior of slaves, both those who remained at home and those who accompanied their masters into the army. Letters of January and February 1865 advise Mrs. Bratton as to what she should do if the Yankees approach her home.

researchRecord.name: 1890, 5 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from General Bratton of Farmington, Fairfield County, South Carolina, to William G. Hinnant, Chairman of the [Democratic] "Committee", April 21, 1890, concerning the political situation in the state.

researchRecord.name: 1861-1865, 150 items on 1 microfilm reel.
researchRecord.description: A few letters were written before the beginning of the Civil War. Those written during the Civil War shed light on the attitudes of the upperclass during the conflict. The original papers are in private hands.

researchRecord.name: 1895, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Bratton to Mr. Robert Coates of New York, written on January 25, 1895. In the letter, John Bratton recounts his exhilaration and anxiety during the bombardment of Ft. Sumter. A finding aid is available in the repository and online.
